s.text: Samples of 10 ?l were transferred to a 384-well plate and dried completely; the pellet was dissolved before printing in 5 ?l of 150 mM phosphate pH 7.0 buffer to yield approximately 300 ng/?l DNA concentration.

Flower development provides one example where organs of distinctive morphologies (sepals, petals, stamens, carpels) are produced in rapid succession; specification of each floral organ requires temporally and spatially refined expression of specific genes [ 1].

Comparisons of full-length cDNA sequences of each gene would increase the fractions of gene families both within and between these two libraries.

Third, multiple probes for each of several gene family members for five families deposited at random positions generated similar hybridization patterns (Figure 2), suggesting that local effects on hybridization were negligible.
To some extent these quantitative differences may reflect the different properties of microarray and RNA blot hybridizations.
In the available studies, however, there are many examples of maize duplicated genes expressed in different organs [ 46].

These results imply that the differentiated state of maize tissues and organs is characterized by combinations of small numbers of differentially expressed (> 4-fold) tissue- or organ-specific genes among the 5,376 genes in this study.

Each organ is expected to have a unique combination of expressed genes, allowing organ identification and assessment of similarity with other organs as shown by the cladograms in Figure 2. It is interesting that the highly expressed genes in husks parallel what is found in other floral organs.

Among the 12 samples, adult leaf blades (L9-L10) showed the highest number of genes expressed at a lower level than the reference organ (Table 2, and see extensive green color within Figure 2), whereas the husks and silks showed the opposite trend (extensive red color in Figure 2).
